reviews/14/text:
The restored 1945 built tram runs from Sintra through villages and wooded countryside the the beach at Praia da Maças. The journey takes 45 - 50 minutes. The tram is NOT accessible to wheelchairs. Steps up inside. It seats only 24 with a few standing. On weekdays tickets must be bought before boarding at the Vila Alda shop next door to the tram stop. At weekends tickets are sold on board. It is first come, first served. Alas the service has been reduced to only three journeys each day, so get there early.

The first 10 minutes is a steep downhill descent, with much screeching of brakes and squealing of flanges as the tramcar tries to get away. There is a hairpin bend at the end of that section, after which the line undulates through neat villages and wooded hills. The terminus at Praia da Maças is next to the beach.

Parts of the ride are very bumpy and most of the seats are the original wooden ones.

It's a pleasant trip, but there is not much effort made to expand the experience. Just go for the ride.

reviews/18/text:
This was easily one of our best days in Portugal. Sintra is a must-see but it’s a very full day, so leave early and plan ahead. Without a doubt, the dazzling Disney-land like Pena Palace was the highlight.
TIPS:
i) TRAIN – the train from Rossio Station at Lisbon couldn't have been easier. Using a Via Viagem rechargeable card, it cost €4.50 return, departs frequently and was a 40 min direct trip. Car parking is very tricky in Sintra.
ii) ITINERARY – there is so much to see in Sintra that if you don't want to be a slave to your itinerary, you need to make tough choices beforehand about what to see and what to skip. We had 7 hours which was enough time to see the Pena Palace and Park, to hike from the Moors castle to the town centre, have lunch and see the Sintra National Palace. I would have loved to see Quinta de Regaleira but we reluctantly decided that this was too much for 1 day.
iii) TIMING - We arrived at just after 10am. In hindsight, we should have left earlier. Even an hour earlier would have made a big difference to the Pena Palace queues. This is the busiest place where the queues are longest so best to make this your first stop. 
iv) VOLTA DO DUCHE – it’s an easy, flat 10 min walk between the train station and town centre, along the Volta do Duche road. On the way, you’ll see the palace-like Town Hall and pillory, Liberdade Park and a great collection of modern sculptures. 
v) TOURIST INFORMATION – this was the only place we found maps easily. It's located in the centre of town and free walking trails and brochures as well as a ticket office and spotless bathrooms. 
vi) NATIONAL PALACE – The town skyline is dominated by the strikingly unusual two white towers. This palace doesn't get the attention it deserves because of the Pena Palace but it's very beautiful and is easy to visit, being right in the town centre.
vii) CASCAIS? – Several friends suggested catching an uber home and popping into Cascais on the way back but I can't imagine less than a full day in Sintra. We went to Cascais another day instead and it deserves at least half a day on its own, and a full day if you have the time.

description:
Part of the historic Quinta da Reglaeira estate, this deep well features a gothic spiral staircase that descends around 88 feet underground to a maze of tunnels. This mysterious well was said to be used for ceremonial purposes and tarot initiation rites. Admire the depths and moss-covered walls from above, before entering the well and exploring the tunnels, that will lead you to the gardens. Just remember a flashlight as it can be dark.

There are often long lines, so visit right after opening, or at closing time for fewer crowds. Join a guided estate tour of Quinta da Reglaeira to learn more about its curious history. – Tripadvisor

reviews/3/text: Far less celebrated than the over-hyped Pena Palace high above Sintra, the National Palace is refreshingly free of mobs and offers a more relaxed and direct experience with the site itself. The highlight is undoubtedly the Heraldry Room -- the westernmost room in the westernmost palace in Europe -- with its carved wooden vault of royal and noble seals that wouldn't be out of place in "Game of Thrones." Signature kitchen chimneys that rise nearly a hundred feet make this an instantly recognizable and photogenic location. The walk from the (maddening) train station takes in some exquisite views of the town and valley. Our visit here salvaged what could have been a disastrous day of non-sightseeing owing to Sintra's inflated reputation and hordes of non-discriminating visitors.

reviews/0/text:
We visited this palace on September 22. Free parking is available on the other side of the entrance. After paying the entrance fee you have to walk to the palace. On the map you see two routes: the blue one is the easiest and the red one is more challenging.
The rooms in this palace are not fully furnished. The architecture is what sets this palace apart from the others in Sintra. A film is shown on the second floor about the last inhabitant of this place.
reviews/1/text: We were so happy we included this palace as part of our exploration of Sintra and definitely recommend it.  We found the palace and grounds to be magical, especially in the latter part of the day. The grounds are a bit wild giving a sense of mystery and contrast to the perfect interiors of the palace.  The palace  itself is Moorish and just lovely in its reconstruction.  Be sure to visit the top floor where you can see pictures of its occupants and learn its history - a bygone era. It was easy to get an Uber to/from as the bus didn't seem to run regularly.
reviews/1/title: Include Monserrate on your tour of Sintra
reviews/2/text:
Well worth the extra time it takes to visit compared to the other attractions. Monseratte felt  like a magical fairytale. We went after a rainfall and the air was wet and aromatic, so the garden smelt heavenly. The rose garden air was thick and almost syrupy with the floral scent. I would highly recommend it!
The palace itself was stunning. I recommend getting the audio guide to walk you through the grounds and rooms, however, there is also a room on the top floor that has an very informative video on the history and ownership of the palace. 
The only caveat is that the park and palace close after the bus stops running, so my friends and I got stranded. Be prepared to take an Uber back if you really want to take your time! It's worth it. 
You could do it in 2-3 hours but with how gorgeous it is, you could also spend 3+ there.
reviews/3/text:
This palace was definitely one of my favourite sites in Sintra. 

I’m so thankful it was decided to renovate and restore this beautiful building, and it’s grounds, to its former glory.

The palace is exquisite, as are the gardens. I purposely arrived early so as to enjoy the palace before it started getting busier. 

There’s a lovely little café on site which sells a great selection of cakes.

I would highly recommend visiting the Palace of Monserrate, and I would definitely come back here again.
reviews/4/text:
Easy day trip from LIsbon, train from Rossio to Sintra (last stop), 45 minutes. Outside the trainstation is the 435 bus, which does a route of the attractions (different bus than Pena Palace). Some of the routes down to the palace are steep, on entrance the shortest route is marked to the left but this is wrong, it is best to go to the right and then follow the signs. The park and palace (which is small but very beautiful) are well worth a visit and more impressive than the Pena Palace. Bring a picnic and have it here if the weather is good. Extremely quiet - no crowds. 
There is a small coffee shop for drinks and ice cream.
reviews/5/text: Parque de Monserrate was by far my favourite location in Sintra. We chose to go there by foot (a 5 km walk from the historical center in Sintra) and it was totally worth it. We enjoyed the nature around us and the serenity it offered. The Parque has luxurious gardens and the palace withing is just stunning.
reviews/6/text: Sintra area has few castles to offer. As each of them is different, each person finds his favorite castle. This one offers a beautiful garden full of flowers and plants form all around the world. I was taking pictures and sending them to my friend that just loves plants. If you are a person for that, this is a place to go!
reviews/6/title: For fans of flowers and plants
reviews/7/text: We walked from Sintra town up to Parque de Montserrate passing  through the lovely narrow roads, about 1 hour or so. This palace and gardens is not so popular as the other palaces around Sintra but very well worth the visit. Marvellous grounds and an unusual palace full of history.
reviews/8/text:
You can't miss this place! 
The gardens are full of history with plants and trees from all over the globe. 
Magical to say the least! The Palace is magnificent and you won't feel this location as crowded as other monuments in Sintra. 
A true special place!
reviews/9/text: Probably the most iconic private house built by the British in Portuguese soil. Extraordinary architecture and very extensive and diverse gardens.
reviews/10/text: Surrounded by beautiful gardens, this is well worth a visit. there is a lot of walking but it is well worth a visit.
reviews/11/text:
We were shocked by how beautiful the grounds were, even in January.  They're beautifully maintained, and well worth an hour or two of wandering.

The palace has been wonderfully restored;  you have to see the 'before' pictures to fully appreciate the work that has been done.  I wish we'd have been told to start on the top floor.  This is where all of the information about the history of the palace is.  There's a very interesting video to watch, as well.  I highly suggest starting at the top and working your way down; it will all make much more sense that way.

We stopped at the cafe, and it's a nice place for a drink and a snack (inside or out).  The selection of food is likely much better during high season.

Beware if you're driving to Monserrate - good old google maps sent us to the service entrance (a challenging drive to be avoided at all costs).  This might be a disappointing place for anyone with mobility issues.  Wear proper footwear as the paths can be steep and slippery in places.  

Would LOVE to see this place in summer (although, I fear the crowds would be annoying).
reviews/11/title: Beautiful gardens and interesting history inside the palace.  Worth a visit!
reviews/12/text: The grounds of Monserrate were so much less crowded than the other palaces we had visited in Sintra, which meant more time to stop for photos, enjoy the moment and imagine what life must have been for its inhabitants all those years ago. The fern valley was especially special, as the lush greenery left us with a sense of peace, almost like stumbling into a lost world or forgotten Eden. The expansive garden make for good exploration but prepare for lots of walking! Due to the proximity to the Quinta de Regaleira, it makes sense to visit these two sights in Sintra if all you have is a day trip in this enchanting town.
reviews/13/text: I just loved to visit Monserrat and was raining. The garden is beautiful, as well as the view. the structure and architecture of the palace is amazing. I'm totally in love with this place. I will return some day during hot season to see the rose garden with flowers.
reviews/14/text: We would have liked to walk around the town, as well as organize visits to at least a couple palaces, but none of them were accessible. For that reason, we could only visit Montserrate. It was fun and we spent an hour there. On the whole Portugal is a challenge for people with accessibility issues.
reviews/14/title: The one palace in Sintra that was accessible
reviews/15/text: The extensive grounds are exceedingly well maintained and so much more interesting than the Pena Palace grounds which get the tourist flocks. Even in October there were flowers blooming which can't be said for Pena. The pathways are well laid out and views well chosen. Wonderful cafe-do stop in!
reviews/16/text: This was one of my favourite places to see in Sintra and I wish I hadn't left it until the day I had to leave.  The gardens are gorgeous and I imagined sipping champagne with some great girlfriends of the fabulous lawn.  The villa itself is also very beautiful.
reviews/17/text: a wonderful oasis and plenty of places to find peace and quiet away from the crowds. Its worth going when the day trippers have left for the day
reviews/18/text: Fantastic, a piece of paradise. Beautiful gardens full of colour. Lovely architecture well worth the visit. 8 euros per person. Absolute worth every penny.
reviews/18/title: Get away from the hustle and bustle
reviews/19/text: The garden is divided in a few areas : the rose garden, Mexican garden, ... it's all well maintained and very pleasant to walk around through these variety of plants, trees and flowers with all the different colors and smells. The garden is very big so you don't suffer from other tourists, very quiet and pieceful. Also the palace is not so crowded either. The palace is majestic and well preserved. Be sure to take some time to visit Monserrate, you won't regret is. We stayed for about 1h30

Amazing beach! Great hike! Actually a bit difficult!

The beach is hard to get to and the trail is not only a maze but a bit dangerous. No one knows how to get to the beach, so don't follow a random person. If you are facing the beach and go right, you are going the wrong way.

Wait for a person who is coming back from the beach and ask them for directions! 

Bring a backpack not a totebag, wear sneakers or boots, bring a layer, and don't give up.
reviews/1/text: All is well.. Guys go and enjoy life... That was a beautiful sunny day.. Me with my friends explore this area... AMAZING WEATHER AND BEAUTIFUL SCENERY
reviews/1/title: You can spend one day beautiful
reviews/2/text:
Some tips:

1. Wear  snickers, not sandals or flip flops, as you can slip.

2. The climb is a bit steep on some areas, so you will need to rely on your legs and hands.

3. There are no amenities on the beach, so bring some drinks and snacks with you.

4. The water is very cold and there are many waves.

5. You will encounter some nudists.

6. There are places where you can park the car/motorcycle.

We've spent a lovely day and we will return there; it felt very peaceful.
reviews/3/text:
If you don't mind hiking, then do it.  The views are worth it, even if you don't make it down to the beach, just take a walk to the clifs' edge above.
Just a short way down from Cabo da Roca, kill two birds with one stone.
reviews/3/title: Worth the track thru the dunes
reviews/4/text: One of the most beautiful beaches in Europe, easy to get there and not expensive at all. Portugal offers the best options to spend a week off of the routine.
reviews/5/text:
The best b-day. The extremely outstanding view. But if wants to reach this beach you need to climb up/down.... In any case it is worth it. Rocks, sand, atlantic ocean.... 
Must see...
reviews/6/text: Beautiful view! It's worth visiting, but if you prefer a beach to relax and spend the day, there are many other beaches for you to choose from. This is a quick visit for pictures. A lot of tourists visit because it is the westernmost point in Europe.
reviews/7/text: I found Cabo da Roca to be beautiful and the ocean crashing against the cliffs. There are some hiking trails to explore, well worth the trip out here.
reviews/8/text: Worth a quick stop. If you have time to hike and like to hike I would as long as the weather conditions are mild. The wind and wet rocks makes it dangerous for hiking. Had a feeling like being at table top in South Africa or even giants causeway in Ireland.
reviews/9/text: I read in several forums that the “Bear Beach” is a quite secret spot with not too many people and not far away from Cabo da Roca, as you have to climb a rocky and sandy path down. I took bus number 403 to Cabo da Roca (either from Sintra or Cascais), stayed there for 15 minutes, and started walking down the road until a small path came into sight on the left where I turned in. It can be recognised easily because it is the first path where cars can drive in and park there. Just follow the path and you’ll be fine. The climb down was not as scary as described on some pages on the Internet, but I would still recommend you to wear sturdy shoes and pay full attention to your steps because the road is very slippery due to the fine sands and small rocks. In my opinion, normal fitness condition is required, children/teens can do that hike as well. When the way splits up, take the left path which is the easier one to hike. After about 35 minutes (10 minutes walk from Cabo da Roca to the path not included) I was finally on the beach, so make sure you have enough time planned if you want to watch the sunset. Be aware of the rocks on the beach, they may hurt you. Now, it was time to lay down in the soft natural sand and relax, or to take beautiful photographs of the magnificent landscape, or observe the wild waves of the Atlantic Ocean splashing on rock formations and the beach. After sunset, you have about 30 minutes to climb up before the sky darkens completely. You’ll be able to catch one of the last busses at Cabo da Roca or just call a taxi. Notice that there is no reception, no Internet, no toilet available on the beach and it might get quite windy on some days, so make sure you are prepared and have everything you need in your day pack!
reviews/9/title: Best sunset I’ve seen so far
reviews/10/text: This was part of a day trip from Lisbon before going to Sintra. The beauty of the ocean and its cliffs are spectacular. Cabo da Roca being the most western point of continental Europe is a must see
reviews/11/text: Really beautiful but only for those who are agile as it can get quite steep. It took us about 30 minutes to get down to the beach and wow......it was a page out of paradise! Highly recommended for those who are agile and not afraid of heights.
reviews/12/text: I almost don't want to say how beautiful this place was so that it doesn't become overrun with visitors! Staying in Sintra for a few days I took an uber over to the coast and it was literally the highlight of my trip. Have no worries about taking an uber there and then calling a new one when you're done.. there was good cell phone service and there were cars very nearby. I didn't hike all the way down to the beach (though there was a trail where you could) but sitting on the cliffs above with a good book and looking down made for a more than pleasant afternoon. If you're planning to hike down good footwear would be a must.
reviews/13/text: Lovely pedestrian track along the ocean coast leading to one of the most beatiful beaches of Portugal.
reviews/14/text: Just the hike by itself is amazing, the view, the adventure, you can take amazing pictures. We took a longer and more difficult way cause we didn’t know how to get there but it all ended well, the beach is amazing, unfortunately the weather changed while we where on the trail, but the beach was still nice, cold water btw
reviews/15/text: Our hotel host recommended we visit this beach and we are so grateful. It is one of the most beautiful places I've ever seen. It's important to note that the hike down to the beach is rocky, steep and sometimes slippery. Bring good athletic shoes. When you arrive the beauty of the beach will take your breath away. If you plan to stay and enjoy it, bring water and food as there are no amenities (including no public restrooms). Worth it all!
reviews/15/title: Worth the hike to see this amazing beach!
reviews/16/text: This beach is an amazing work of art of Mother Nature. Sintra is worth visiting just to go to Praia da Ursa. Make sure you bring the right shoes, you’ll have to do some hiking down and up to access the beach. The water is really cold!!! But the view is totally worth it.
reviews/17/text: Made the tour from Lisbon to the Atlantic coast by motorbike. Beautiful area, fresh air and good waves for surfing. Mainly Portugiese tourists. Very difficult to find accommodation if you did not make a reservation well in advance.
reviews/18/text:
Not for beginners.. get prepared with proper shoes 👟, not bring any heavy stuff besides backpack 🎒..
Long way to walk down to the beach with some challenges..
Beach is great; amazing views but water close to freeze..
Based on difficult to reach place.. don’t expect to see many people around..
No network.. cannot connect or use phones..
reviews/18/title: Amazing Beach not easy to reach ..
reviews/19/text: We did not go to the Lighthouse which was full of tourist buses and headed directly to Ursa Beach. An amazing place.  It is hard to reach it, the road is very steep, so do not risk to go there if it rains, it can be very dangerous to go on the slippery rocks. We came just before the rain, and it was incredible, Few people, so the beach is all for yourself. TIP: take a lunch box and enjoy your time.
reviews/19/title: Stunning wild beach, a real gem!!

description:
This fairytale-like country estate and UNESCO World Heritage Site located near Sintra’s historic center is known for its beautiful architecture, landscaped gardens, and the eerie Initiation Wells. Take a guided tour of the property to learn more about its enthralling history, and explore other mysteries like the underground tunnels, grottoes, chapel, and more. The estate gets busy so visit once it opens for a quieter experience; tickets often sell out too so book early to secure your slot.

Explore Quinta da Regaleira on a tour of Sintra, which often includes stops at other iconic sights like Pena Palace and Roca Cape. 

– Tripadvisor

reviews/0/text: Do not miss out on this if you are in the area! It is beautiful, magical, and mystical. One of the most interesting and amazing places that I have ever visited.
reviews/1/text: What a lovely place! The highlight of the visit was the Initiation Well, which is a magical and magnificent place. Expect queues, though, as it's a famous place. We paid 11 euros per person to go into Quinta da Regaleira, which was totally worth it, as it's a massive place with loads of lovely gardens and little caves to explore. The Regaleira Palace was also stunning with its wooden ceilings. I was surprised when we got to Sintra by train, though. Although it's super cheap 4.60 euros per person round trip and only takes 40 minutes, I didn't expect the little town to be flooded with tourists! There are two main buses, the 434 which is a hop on hop off and costs 12.50 euros per person to go to different places but we opted to go to Regaleira only, so we took the 435 which is a small bus costing 5.50 per person. Badly organised, it only turns up every 30 minutes and doesn't seem big enough for the amount of people who want to ride it. When we finished at the Regaleira, the bus never turned up so we ended up taking a taxi, which cost so little (3.45 euros) that made me wonder why I didn't take the taxi to go up there in the first place! Apart from the stress regarding transport, the day trip was lovely and I would totally recommend it.
reviews/2/text:
This place is a jewel and a must visit in Sintra. Unfortunately it was packed with tourists. I would advice to go as early as it opens to avoid the crowds annoying tourists not particularly interested in visiting the place, rather just ticking the "touristic" box and taking Instagram photos. 

The nature is outstanding and the architecture breathtaking.
reviews/2/title: One of the most beautiful places I have been - A must go!
reviews/3/text: Quirky house and beautiful grounds.  Definitely worth the time if you're in Sintra.  Not a bad walk from the city center.
reviews/3/title: Quirky house and beautiful gardens in Sintra
reviews/4/text: Best stop in sintra.  Beautiful grounds.  Not crowded like Pena.  Initiation well was the only place that was crowded.  Still worth it.  The caves at the bottom were awesome.  Just loved the grounds at this place.
reviews/5/text: This was one of our highlights in Portugal. We were transported to a movie like garden and castle. The property is filled with many tales and exploring it will allow you to believe them! I’d recommend several hours here.
reviews/6/text: It was a rainy & foggy day as we ventured to view the vast estate of Quinta Da Regaleira but it seemed to add to its mystique. One of the most famous architectural components are the Initiation Wells which contain a winding staircase. It is said to carry symbolic meaning including death and rebirth. However, not much is known about its function as it was not a well used to store water. It is believed to have been used for secrative initiation rites related to Masonry and the Knights Templar. There are those that speculate the various attributes such as the nine platforms are “reminiscent of the Divine Comedy by Dante and the nine circles of Hell, the nine sections of Purgatory and the nine skies which constitute Paradise.” In any case, this was a site worth visiting and likely worth visiting more than once in order to really explore all the areas of this beautiful and mysterious estate. #quintadaregaleira #initiationwell
reviews/6/title: Quinta Da Regaleira & Masonic Initiation Wells
reviews/7/text: If you visit the Lisbon area but don’t have a lot of time, spend a day in Sintra to visit the Pena Palace in the morning and Quinta da Regaleira in the afternoon.
reviews/8/text:
This was probably my favourite out it Peña and Moorish Castle.  It’s also easy to reach on foot from the town.

Spectacular gardens and the well and castle are equally enchanting.

It’s quite hilly so you’ll do a few steps that day.

March is a good time to visit as it’s probably packed in the summer
reviews/9/text: Amazing beautiful  place.we really loved it,beautiful gardens.The quinta da Regaleira is a must to visit
reviews/10/text: Fascinating and relaxing. Within walking distance of Sintra village. Not busy when we visited in March. Nice cafe. The audio guide was good. Informative but not too detailed.
reviews/11/text: Great grounds. Beautiful and well kept. House was under major renovations so we were only able to see a small part. Would love to go back once they are completed.
reviews/12/text: Absolute musthave. Don’t use day tours, go by Yourself by train from Lisbon, train ticket is ~3-4eur. Walk from station is ~15-20min - note that 434 bus at time of arrival of train is overflooded, that’s why I recommend walk frist to Regaleira and then check other attractions. Entrance ticket 11eur - spend time in garden, explore all attractions there, including well. I would say 2h would be enough. Garden is very beautiful. We cought 434 bus from historical center, bought 1 ticket for 4,5eur (and not hop on hop of for 12,5) and via train station ride to Pena palace and later walked to Moorish castle and from there on foot back to station (this walk is only downhill)
reviews/12/title: Great garden, palace views and magical initiation well
reviews/13/text:
Would rate as number 2 thing to do in Sintra (after the Pena Palace) but my main tip would be to do this last thing in the day, especially if travelling back to Lisbon on the train. Why? Because it is then an easy walk back to the train station instead of fighting the crowds down from the Palace or Castle.
We found that to get the most out of each place, it is difficult to do more than two sites in the day. And this was on a ‘low’ tourist day..
The house is interesting but the highlight is the gardens. So much to explore, especially the grottos at the bottom of the Initiation Well, which itself is like stepping back to medieval times.
Wander back to the train station and plenty of little gift shops to look in. Allow at least 3 hours including the walk to train station, so perfect to do after lunch.
reviews/14/text: Absolutely loved this! Gorgeous gardens, beautiful buildings, loads to see and do. Especially loved the spiral staircase and caves
reviews/15/text:
What a beautiful, unique place! Try to get to the Well first on top of the hill and take it down to the bottom. It isn't strenuous to do, and what you will find below will simply amaze you! Once you're back outside, the gardens and ornamentation all over, will find you taking picture after picture! 
There's an outside cafe that ppl were enjoying even in Feb. and the inside rooms of the palace (main floor only) have beautiful Gothic Revival and Neo-Manueline architectural features definitely worth seeing. There is no doubt why this is classified as a World Heritage Site by UNESCO.
reviews/16/text: It was so, so busy, and only February... Summer must be crazy. Very hard to get parked, but found somewhere a way down the hill. But so worth persevering. Loved my visit... Worth it for the well alone..
reviews/17/text: We had a great morning here. We got the train from Rossio and walked from the station.  We arrived at 10 and it wasn’t too busy. We opted for the audio tour which I would recommend as we could stroll around and explore at our own pace. There were so many incredible sites to see. It was most definitely a highlight of our stay in Lisbon. Don’t miss out!
reviews/18/text: I enjoyed climbing around the structures and the natural beauty on this estate.  The ritual well was phenomenal.  The biggest surprise for me on the property was discovering a deep grotto that I wandered through.   Beautiful and meditative.
reviews/18/title: Phenomenal nature, interesting structures, very spiritual experience
reviews/19/text:
What can I say! This palace is beautiful and stunning! Far nicer than Peña Palace! Go here over there! 

We went in Feb and arrived at 11:00 very little crowds and we were able to amble at our own pace!

This grounds are something out of a fairytale. There are caves, ponds, wells, waterfalls and it’s just wonderful. My partner and I had a lovely couple of hours here.

Got a bit busier into the afternoon so maybe earlier is best. 

Easy to access by car and right next to the historical centre. 

Highly highly recommend!!

No notice, no announcement, no nothing, the workers in Peña palace just went on to strike, and the palace was closed. We got there early and was directed by police to park in a faraway location. The cop did not bother to tell us the park was closed. We parked and start walking towards the palace, a tour guide told us the palace was not open. What a shock!

The park reopened at 2:30pm, and what a disaster! We decided to forgo the Peña palace, it’s a good decision. According people who went that day, the park was chaotic, full with people, long lines everywhere. 

Make sure you call the place first before you go.
reviews/2/title: Terrible experience, Peña palace went on strike!
reviews/3/text:
I had limited time in Sintra and had to weigh which attractions I had to give up which I had to visit. This castle ranks the top on my list and I visited in the morning before it became too crowded. 

There's a bus from centre of Sintra going round the various scenic spots including this one. Everyone buys a one-day pass so to be able to hop on and off. 

There are only one or two staff. People mainly purchased tickets for entrance at the ticket machine which doesn't work well at all. 

Wow! The views are stunning from this castle and I enjoy so much the climbing!  Simply a GORGEOUS and GREAT place not to be missed in Sintra!
reviews/4/text: A must in Sintra, great step back in history, beautiful ruins with great views. Quite a hike if you wanna get there on foot from the train station
reviews/5/text: Some kind of strike. We had tickets for 1pm but all doors are closed, no service people.. a lot of people waiting..
reviews/6/text:
The Castle is a ruin on the hill overlooking Sintra.  It is not far from the Pena Palace in the same area.  The castle is essentially a ruin, so there is not that much to see if you like a reconstructed castle, but is is a great place to walk and I expect kids or teens would love it.  I can't comment on the view as it was foggy the day I was there, but the fog just added to the mystery and feel of the ruins.

Apparently there is a bus from the valley townsite to the castle, but if you are fit I would highly recommend walking up the path through the forest instead.
reviews/7/text:
We started the morning there. We had got off the train from Rossio, Lisbon and had got a taxi up to this fortress (€10 for 4 people). We were not in the mood for the crowded bus that day and only wanted to see a couple of the sights in Sintra.
Booked the tickets from from Parques de Sintra website directly.
(As it turns out no queue at the ticket machine)
After our visit, we walked up to Palacio de la Pena around 12.30( 10/15 mn walk). Bought the tickets online again, avoided the queue at ticket machine. Got a 1 o'clock slot to visit the Palace, small queue to get in. Got the tuk tuk back down to the historical center (€15). All worked out perfect.
reviews/8/text: Catching the early morning train to Sintra from Oriente, took a little over an hour. Exiting the northern side of Sintra Station which was the end of the railway line, we waited in line with other tourists to catch the regular tourist bus to the Moorish Castle with the building crowd. When the bus stopped outside the gate to Castelo dos Mouros, most tourists stayed onboard to go to the next Palace stop. Tickets from the auto machine at the front gate took forever, due to a machine not working, but the wait was worth it. Fabulous, though not ideal for anyone experiencing walking difficulties. Just enjoy what we still have the opportunity to visit. We felt it was a wise move for us to exit the tourist bus at the 1st stop when there were no crowds, which we experienced later in the day. Upon leaving we caught the next packed tourist bus to Pena Palace.
reviews/8/title: Worth the Euro's - Stunning views inside & out.
reviews/9/text: We arrived close to closing time and there were very few people. This was so nice after having spent time earlier in the day at the Pena Palace sandwiched between people. It was fun to walk the walls and take in the amazing views of Sintra. We didn't need much time to walk the walls, climb the stairs and check out the cisterns. Our walk back to town was enjoyable too! Look for the friendly cats when you're there.
reviews/10/text:
The Skip-The-Line Pass I had ended up being worthless, the lack of crowd by the time I arrived after Pena Palace simply not requiring anything like it, but I'm certainly glad I walked over there because of it when I finished the former, because this castle offers perhaps the greatest views I have ever seen without being in some form of plane or skyscraper.

The history is perhaps a little lighter than I'd hope for what must have been an astounding architectural feat by the Moors, building such a fort so high in the mountains, but the views simply overwhelm my opinion on the castle. Climbing the stone-hewn steps, I almost felt like a cinematic adventurer with the Atlantic wind dangerously close to lifting me away down the hill and no railings to save me (yeah, I would warn you, it was exhilarating but did feel a tad perilous at moments on the walls themselves, and I'm still a youngish man)
reviews/10/title: Greatest Views in the Lisbon Area? Worth facing treacherous wind for!
reviews/11/text: We had great views of the castle ruins and wall from Pena Palace but didn't have time to get closer, unfortunately. Next time (Ihopefully)!
reviews/12/text: Been to many castles but this one due to the views and dramatic location ranks highly. It is on the top of a hill that has sheer drops on one side and dramatic views on all side. To get to the castle I would advise catching a tuk tuk or the land train from the train station as the winding hill road is steep and very busy.   When inside you can walk the entire battlements but beware of the wind that comes off the Atlantic. There are many great photo spots within and from the walls. Its worth the journey up the mountain
reviews/13/text: The Moorish Castle was an adventure.  We had a great day exploring the ruins. The line up at the ticket booth was long so while in line I bought the tickets on website and saved 5%. There is wifi in the area. A little more direction and staff presence would be helpful. You could wash go around for free as we did not see anyone to show our tickets. You can walk around the walls of the castle but if you are somewhat afraid of heights you might want to reconsider. Lots of kids there but I would be nervous with them.
reviews/14/text:
Beautiful views and a great day out.
Walked up from the town through the park, was quite an adventure! (lacking a few signs so got a bit lost!)
The castle itself, wow!
Interesting history and well maintained.

Small cafe at the top, which although small had a good selection.
reviews/15/text:
When buying Peña Palace tickets, we bought Moorish Castle tickets as well, as there was a slight discount.
Did Peña Palace first, then walked down to Moorish Castle, which is about 350m walk.
The initial entrance takes you through paths with plants and trees, and good views.
If you hadn’t bought tickets previously, at the main entrance where the person checks your tickets, you can buy tickets from the automatic booths if you need to.
The walk around the walls is suggested to be one way, start at the right and go around.  Some areas are quite narrow, so it is best to go one way, however some people do like to do their own thing!
Quite steep at times, and high, so not great for those with poor mobility or fear of heights.
Fantastic views on a clear day, and, once at the final top peak, you will get a great view of Peña Palace up on it’s hill at the rear of Moorish Castle.
Free toilets and a basic cafe, but plenty of seating.
reviews/16/text: The history of Sintra starts at this place.  It is located just below Pena Castle and give you a realistic idea how all started. If you try to imagine how this was done centurys ago,…
reviews/17/text: Nice area and nice walk to the castle. If you have difficulty walking, it is difficult to approach castle / ruins. Only downside grumpy sandwich seller, who very was unfriendly snapped at a customer because she was carrying her mini dog in a baby carrier. Ok it'was forbidden, but it was pouring rain and there was almost nowhere to hide, where is the compassion? Also he could have react, normal instead of screaming. But how hard is it to warm up a sandwich, chicken was frozen inside, maybe less surfing on the computer.
reviews/17/title: Beautiful view from different point views! Only cateringseller very grumpy, that is why average score
reviews/18/text: I cannot tell a lie. Actually, I can, but I won't here. I didn't go to the castle. I wanted to, but the way my wife was walking, there was no was way she was going to make it. So we had to content ourselves with seeing it frm afar, as we did from multiple locations. In truth, it looked great, from whatever angle we saw it. And it seems you can see it from almost everywhere nearby. Maybe I will get there on our next trip. My wife can stay in the car.
reviews/19/text: Awesome place to visit, great views of the area as you are up high! We went up a walking path to the top which took a while and was tiring,  but there are also buses that take you up there and also to the other castles/attractions in Sintra. One of my top favorites in Portugal !

reviews/1/text: Stunning gardens and walks with terrific views of Pena palace and Lisbon in the distance. A brilliant day trip from Lisbon with easy access to reach from the city. Online tickets should be easier to buy however, the website was not very good so we had to pay when we arrived where there is long queues. *park visit only*
reviews/1/title: Excellent day out to Sintra exploring the Pena Palace park
reviews/2/text: Beautiful park but we bought 4 tickets to visit the palace at 13.45 and no one told us we had to wait until 16.00, sadly we had the train to go back to Lisbon at 16.30 so we wasted out Money.
reviews/3/text: I wouldn’t go back.  Crowds were ridiculous even at 10 am.  Much of exterior was under renovation and covered.  If arriving by train, take an uber.  It was only 3.5 euros.  And far easier than dealing with the crowds and the bus.  It was only a 2 minute wait for an uber...which was faster than the whole process of a line trying to get on the bus.
reviews/4/text: Amazing palace with amazing culture. Great experience with wonderful knowledge acquired. Everything is organised and clean, and the staff is very friendly
reviews/5/text: We loved traipsing through the castle and were grateful for the suggestion of taking a Tuk-Tuk both to & from the train. Seeing the amazing colors and touring each room was very interesting as we learned the history of the palace and Portugal as well.
reviews/6/text: Beautiful. Stunning. I'm so happy we saw it. We pre-booked an entry slot at 12:30. We did the Castle first and gave ourselves enough time. The park itself is big. There's plenty to walk around and see on the way up to the Palace. We arrived at the entrance and there were hundreds of people. We arrived at 11:45 and the Security Man said we were too early and that the two queues were for 11:30 and 12:00. At 12:00 he said the same but after 5mins we decided to walk up and I am glad we did as our time slot was listed on the board and we joined the line at the start. It was good to go in. I wasn't that bothered by the rooms but the building was beautiful, with tiles from floor to ceiling. On a very sunny day like we had the views and the building itself look beautiful. Worth a visit.
reviews/7/text:
This striking, colourful beauty is certainly gorgeous from the outside! The detail on many of the archways’ and doors’ stonework is stunning and both the “plain” and tiled sections are striking and beautiful, often bringing to mind castles in fairytales.
We came here with a private guide who had sensibly told us to book the first ticket slot - excellent advice as even then there were quite a few people around, but by the time we left it was heaving, with huge queues. We were not told to get transfer tickets, so hadn’t, and indeed the 30 minute walk warned about on the website is more like 10-15 minutes. It is uphill, but it is through part of the park and very pretty, although I can imagine it would be slippery on a wet day.
The interior of the palace is a fascinating mix of styles, from the original monastery cloister, incorporated in a Moorish style, to castle-like and stately-home like parts. The chapel, up a separate flight of stairs from the main indoor sections, has the original altarpiece from the monastery and is definitely worth seeing.
But my favourite parts were the great hall and the kitchen!
There are excellent views on a clear day from both sides of the palace - it was a bit misty when we visited but we could still see quite a way.
There is a takeaway style cafeteria selling drinks and snacks on the upper level (although no seating when we visited as they were maintaining the stone slabs on the outdoor seating area) as well as a restaurant and shop downstairs (which bizarrely had no guidebooks in English when we visited - luckily I can manage Spanish!).
Be aware that, although they do apparently help with access as much as possible, those with any issues with stairs will not be able to access the indoor areas at all.
Definitely worth a visit.
reviews/8/text: We visited Pena Palace on a daytrip to Sintra while in Lisbon.  First of all, make sure you get tickets ahead of time on their website.  We arrived early for our timed entry and the line to buy tickets was very long.  Also, you have to get timed tickets and you must arrive at your time, there apparently is no allowance for people who are late.  We arrived at 9:40 for our 10:00 entrance and were the first in line waiting for the 10AM entry.  The park and the outside of the palace are gorgeous.  There are tons of paths and areas to walk around and the nature and birdwatching here is great.  The outside of the palace is very picturesque and the view (when the fog is not there) are stunning.  The inside of the palace was very underwhelming.  You shuffle in line from room to room and there was nothing really mindblowing about it (not like other palaces we've visited).  If I was to recommend it, I'd recommend only buying a park ticket to see the park and the outside of the palace, and skip the inside of the palace ticket.
reviews/8/title: Worth the visit on a day trip to Sintra, the outside visit is better than the inside
reviews/9/text: We booked to enter at 1:00 pm. They opened the palace at 3!  The longest line I ever saw. We were so exhausted, we couldn’t appreciate it. Worthless
reviews/10/text: Got the train from Lisbon to Sintra in order to visit this palace.  We got a taxi from the train station as it's a very, very long way, all uphill.  We booked the tickets online when we got there, and had to wait about 1.5 hours for an entry slot (we got some food at the cafe while we waited, but it was pretty poor food).  I was quite underwhelmed by the castle.  It had some decent views but it's a long way to travel for that, and the castle isn't hugely interesting.  I wouldn't advice anyone to bother with this trip unless they have a real interest in the castle.  We came out to a torrential rain storm, so we got a motor bike carriage ride down the hill, sharing with two other people to keep the cost down.  By doing that we paid 10 euros each for the journey.
reviews/10/title: Okay, but not a must see
reviews/11/text: We finally got here after failing 3 years ago just prior to Covid. That time we had a hire car and I navigated the circular route past the castle ( Never again !!) and couldn't find a parking spot.  This time we got an Uber direct from our hotel in Estoril to the Palace gates for only 13 euro. We had pre-booked times the day before and arrived in plenty of time so had a walk up to the High Cross beforehand.  Queue's were being well monitored and we only waited 30 minutes to get in at 1.30 slot. The rooms inside the castle are well furnished and very interesting with good info on the history and use of the  building. The views of the surrounding countryside are amazing. The gardens are more of a managed forest area but probably worth walking down through The Valley of the Lakes on leaving the castle which gets you back to the entrance. There was a bit of a wait for an Uber to take us back to Estoril as clearly not keen to come round that hairpin road but after 30 mins we got one for only 11 euro. I was later told a short downhill path easily takes you down to Sintra centre but we had visited there 3 years ago so didn' take that option.
reviews/12/text: We decided not to book tickets before leaving  Lisbon but had checked availability before leaving  Lisbon - everything looked fine.  On arriving at Pena Palace was able to book tickets on line for an hour and a half ahead . Walked in the gates (having had our tickets checked) walked up the hill only to be told the palace was not open. Walked back down the hill only to be faced with an hour wait to get back on a bus. Now faced with the task of emailing the crooks to try and get my money back. Not impressed
reviews/13/text: Having high expectations of Peña Palace from photos and descriptions online, I was disappointed by the Peña Palace itself. The outside walls are rather grubby and there is plenty of scaffolding up around the building. Inside, there are lots of descriptive information boards. The park, however, was a delight to walk around, especially the valley of lakes. The bus trip to the top of the mountain was great fun - a bit like a rollercoaster ride.
reviews/14/text: Great extravagant palace. It might take a half day if you wanna enjoy all of it (Park, stables, palace). The palace is worth visiting with original furniture and takes you back in time of the last Kings of Portugal
reviews/15/text: We arrived to Sintra after a 45 minute train journey of being hounded by a busking accordion/tambourine duo. To our dismay on arrival we found out Pena palace was an uphill 75 minute walk. We were continually bombarded by tuktuk drivers with whisperings of strikes and palace closure. They are just after our money we said, and stormed on off uphill. Many minutes passed, no sign of the palace, only path closures forcing us into the arms of a friendly tuktuk driver. The palace will be open at 1pm let me take you he said, and charged us 20€ for the privilege (nearly cost my travel health insurance too may I add). My god have I never seen a queue so huge and gates so firmly closed. Tourists swarming like flies to a cow pat, clueless of the torture they were about to endure. However, I did not see failure as an option, only determination to overcome this challenge. This was to my detriment. One hour of queuing later the gates did open, we thought we’d made it. Oh how wrong we were. A further 30 minute walk uphill through the holy gates, we were struck by yet another queue. This crowd was angrier. Playing dirty. Cutting in. What has happened to us as a human race? Head strong, knees and backs weak, we stubbornly stood in that queue for another 2 hours. In too deep. The paracetamols took no effect. My poor sister was so grumpy she wouldn’t duet high school musical with me. Times were dark. The colourful turrets began to emerge through the trees, restoring hope. How long did it take you to walk around the palace I hear you ask? Alas, it was 15 minutes. Some may argue this is long enough, I’ll leave that with you to decide. Not good enough for me.
reviews/15/title: 4 hour graft, for a 15 minute reward - was it really worth it? Tune in to find out
reviews/16/text:
We self guided and for some fun got a tuk tuk to the the Palace. Lot of fun and rate was 5 euro each. Be careful because apparently some try and charge more.
History of the Palace was interesting and great views. Highly recommend doing this first thing to avoid the crowds. 
If you can, take the time to explore more of the grounds. From the Palace it is a lovely walk down through the Lakes and the Stables, to the Chalet. And very peaceful as most people don’t seem to take the time.  
Number 1 thing to do in Sintra.
reviews/17/text:
Me and my partner made the effort to go to Sintra yesterday and we were both left feeling like we’d paid through the nose for little excitement in return. After taking the train to sintra, the 434 bus attendant tried to pressure us into buying a 24 hour ticket for €12 instead of giving us all the options as a single ticket existed for €4.10. And when we said we wanted that he became rude. We paid the €4.10 as that was all we needed since we were only going to the Peña palace not jumping off anywhere else. The journey was uncomfortable and cramped on the bus, but this was to be expected. 

The ticket then for the palace was €14 each which we paid expecting the grounds and palace to easily be worth it given all the hype the place receives. But the palace once inside was a little underwhelming as you couldn’t go into many rooms and were constantly being pressured to keep moving by how many people were behind you so you only saw things briefly.  The views from the walls however were impressive. 

The grounds though were the  most disappointing thing. There were barely any signposts and the German map/ phone map and distance markers made no sense for what was actually in front of your eyes. We got asked for directions a lot and even we had no clue. They need more signposts, or markers, or maps that actually show ALL the paths. A clearer/recommended route for easy medium and hard walk levels with rough times it will take would be good too as we were so lost at times we barely saw anything and we were wandering for ages. I also had to laugh because some of the tracks were severely steep even for me in my 20’s, yet I heard an attendant say most routes were handicap accessible. Even the castle was not. It had lots of stairs and a one way system that would have forced people to use them. 

We managed to negotiate a €5 each taxi down to the station afterwards with other people so the ride back wasn’t as unpleasant as the 434. Thank god we didn’t buy the all day ticket for 12. To summarise you pay €20-30 for the trip and receive confusion, rude attendants, cramped busses, and steep hills, all for about five minutes with a nice view.

Maybe go once if you want, but avoid peak times in the summer or this will be much much worse than this review.
reviews/18/text: Such a beautiful spot. The architecture, the colours and of course the view. If you have the chance to go, then do. It was the highlight of our Lisbon holiday.
reviews/19/text:
The Pena Palace is a spectacular building situated in beautiful grounds.  If you like, you could spend hours just walking the grounds.  The exterior of the palace is like a fairy tale, and the inside is quite ornate.  There were no line-ups when I was there (January) but the summer might be different.

There are expensive tours to Sintra from Lisbon, but I took the commuter train which was only 6 euros for the return trip, with departure times throughout the day.

reviews/0/text: Absolutely beautiful gem, very few people around and easy to explore.  Architecture was gorgeous and a relaxing place to take a break as well.  If you have a stroller do the handicapped route!  Longer, but much easier!
reviews/1/text: This palace and gardens weren’t originally on our must-see list.  But after reading a rave review, we decided to go. And this turned out to be our favorite experience during our three days in Sintra! Unbelievably gorgeous gardens paths, especially the ferns. But the moss made everything feel a bit magical. The church ruins also incredible, with all the wild nature growing everywhere. Glad there were lots of benches, to just soak up the serene, gorgeous park. And we had just gone because of the reviews of the house. The intricate detail there was also amazing. Definitely visit this place.
reviews/1/title: A feast for your eyes and your heart
reviews/2/text: Truly amazing and remarkable place , beautiful the   architecture is amazing. The park is so beautiful. This an amazing place for all family and dates 🥰
reviews/3/text: Really beautiful & off the beaten path. We did a great loop hike from here to the Convent and back. Probably my favorite day in Portugal in the last 5 weeks. If you want to get away from the crowds spend a little extra time getting here. Probably saw 8 people here.
reviews/4/text: Magical visit. We especially loved the gardens and the tranquil spaces. The palace is well signed throughout and immaculate. Probably our best day out in all the area throughout our 3 days visiting Sintra. Don’t miss !!
reviews/5/text: A fantastic parque and nice to see how life and gardens were made by English decades ago. A real dream. Finally restauration after being abandoned for years.
reviews/5/title: A dream garden. Visit in Summer
reviews/6/text: When I saw the picture of this palace on the internet I said that this is the one place I want to see in Sintra the most. It looked fabulous. The grounds looked very nice, too. Sometimes the pictures make a place look better. Sometimes worse. This time reality exceeded the picture. The exterior is boldly colorful, but not garish, like Pena. When you walk up to it and see it for the first time, you nod your head and say to yourself,”Yep, they nailed it.” The design is imposing.  Very impressive, inside and out, even though the inside is somewhat limited in space, less than you would imagine.  The house actually feels like a real house, like a family would really live there, a real family. It has a Moorish theme and it’s carried off very well. They have a sort of deck around most, if not all the house. It’s nice to walk and look at the surroundings. There are plenty of pathways to walk around. We only walked, pretty much, from the entrance to the house with a minute detour or two. If we had more time, I definitely would have taken advantage of more, as it is a very pleasant atmosphere and I could see visiting if I lived around there just to walk the grounds, Finally, the cafe was closed, perhaps permanently. So we had to go with sandwiches and hot chocolate from vending machines they had there. Both were surprisingly good. The sandwich was on a soft sub shaped roll with a small amount, I think. Not gourmet, but sufficiently filling with the addition of a bag of cookies I shared with my wife. At 2 euros, it was a good deal. My wife agreed. By the way, the bathrooms by the machine were clean, modern and functional.
reviews/7/text: The palace holds little of interest except for the architecture and the astonishing interior. Don't expect rooms full of antique furniture and wall art. However, the history is interesting and  it is a remarkable structure and well worth a visit. However, we came for the gardens/park and were not disappointed. The landscape around the palace is varied and interesting with an extensive variety of planting. The walking paths can be as easy or difficult as you may wish to make it, but everywhere is serene and the paths are well laid out. It is a very restful ambience. There is limited parking nearby and the entrance fee is cheap (6.5 Euros for the over 65s).
reviews/7/title: Beautiful gardens with easy paths for the able bodied
reviews/8/text: Easy to arrive by 435 bus. Not many visitors. The castle is ok . The garden is great. However this place is not incredible as the famous king's castle.
reviews/9/text:
Compared with the Sintra Castle, this attraction is relatively deserted and serene.
The “castle” or more correctly the private residence of a wealthy industrialist has had a chequered history over the centuries and today has been fully restored.

The gardens that surround the castle are well worth a visit on their own and wind through landscaped and rough design alike 

It’s around a 15 minute car trip from Sintra train station and that’s probably the reason why there are so few visitors as getting a taxi or Uber would be quite challenging and expensive
reviews/9/title: Possibly the pick of Sintra attractions
reviews/10/text:
The Palace and Gardens are a wonderful place to visit as stated by many other reviewers. I wanted to add this IMPORTANT NOTE:
If you are driving, the GPS navigation we were using directed us to the N247 out of Sintra. We learned this takes you to the rear locked service entrance of the property. No access is available here. Monserrate is reached using the N375 and the entrance is clearly marked on the road. The GPS may indicate an entrance before you reach the public entrance. Proceed on to the main entrance, well-marked and there is parking available at this point.

It is well worth the visit. I only wished that we hadn’t wasted time with incorrect guidance.
reviews/10/title: Great but be sure you have correct GPS guidance if you are driving
reviews/11/text:
Gorgeous place to visit! It was lovely to be somewhere so pretty and not have crowds of people everywhere. 

Of note: I took an Uber there and expected to take one back down. I could not find a driver to come get me and had to walk back down the the more popular city area.
reviews/12/text:
I won't write a review as there are many here. First time when we visited this place we loved it. It's one of the best places to see in Portugal.
However second time we came with a dog.
Many people ask if it's possible to enter with a dog - no. Animals are not aloud at ALL monuments managed by Parques de Sintra. 

And even a small dog (as a cat) is not allowed. We tried and had to think about other options for the time spending
reviews/13/text: The ornate decor and pleasing gardens make this a fascinating place to visit.  It was not very busy when I was there, which helps!
reviews/14/text:
It’s a great piece of Portuguese story . I was with a guide and the history of this place is amazing 🤩 
The gardens are magical and have some unique plants. 
I did a picnic 🧺  there and was great !
reviews/15/text: This was my favourite palace in Sintra. It's architecture is just stunning. It is a small, but well preserved location, with its own vibe. Inside, you will find information about the history of the palace and the park, along with pieces of art and furniture.
reviews/16/text: Really suggest 2 full days for Sintra, first day for Pena and Muslin Castle, second for Quinta and - my highlight- Montserrate
reviews/17/text: My personal favourite of all the attractions around Sintra. Great architecture and a wonderful atmosphere combine for an unforgettable experience. Don‘t miss it !!!
reviews/18/text: Overall this small palace was beautifully built and kept to high standards throughout time. As many of the furniture was sold off it is quiet sparse. There are many gardens to explore which are beautiful. Was extremely difficult to find via car, would recommend using public transport as much less stressful. Information of history is supplied and was a lovely place to visit and explore.
reviews/19/text:
For some reason, the pictures I saw online put me in mind of Brighton Pavilion. I couldn’t believe there was another fantastic palace to visit in Sintra, albeit a few miles outside. 
This one is more like a mansion than a palace in terms of size, but they were definitely going for palace in terms of decoration. 
Like most of the sights in Sintra, this one is largely unfurnished, for reasons which are explained inside. 
If the gift shop is closed, the attendant will just be at lunch. Come back later. 
Of course, it’s perched on top of a hill and surrounded by mature vegetation (tall trees), so take a drone (if they’re allowed; I have no idea) if you want a good photo of the place.

These charming old brick duck-houses, sitting in the middle of the lake at Pena Park were an unexpected delight. They look like small castles, complete with turrets. Clearly someone had a taste for the whimsical. 
There’s an almost secret garden feeling about this part of the park. The lake is still and serene with dappled sunlight and reflections playing across the water. Lush greenery and ferns surround the lake and large snowy white swans nest along the banks. The whole thing is quite romantic and fanciful. 
The Pena Palace grounds are so extensive, with so many paths and grottos, that it would be easy to miss the lake. To find it, meander slowly down towards the lower exit gate (downhill from the ticket booths).

description: To the west, the Park of Pena also contains the Chalet and Garden of the Countess of Edla, recently reopened to the public after a long process of recovery and restoration after the building was destroyed by fire in 1999. The Chalet was built by King Ferdinand II and his second wife Elise Hensler, Countess of Edla, between 1864 and 1869, in keeping with the Alpine chalet model that was in vogue in Europe at that time. The building is extremely picturesque, characterised by the horizontal marking of the external plaster, painted to imitate timber cladding, and by the extensive use of cork as a decorative element, covering door and window frames, eaves and verandas, as well as tree trunks backing onto the facades to support climbing plants.

reviews/1/text: Old town Sintra has lots of restaurants and tourist shops and the National Palace. It also has the Newsmuseum which I would highly recommend. The museum puts news in context with our modern world and with evolving technology. News has changed and the way it is delivered has all changed. One room deals with the way war has been covered by journalists- and the Vietnam conflict changed everything when correspondents were allowed behind war lines. One room focuses on propaganda and how it grew from a tool of the Catholic Church to a political instrument. Much more is there- make sure to try the virtual reality demonstration at the end to envision how news will get to us in the future.

In an era when news and journalism are under threat, this is a fascinating and important museum. In a modern space it presents an historical account of bringing news, hopefully always impartial, to the citizens of countries.

In the windows it shows notable news makers including Pope Francis, Nelson Mandela and the American and Chinese Presidents.

Over a few floors it presents a multitude of exhibits, both domestic and International, on news, media and communications. A great feature is a spiral staircase that features a news occurrence at each turn of the spiral. 

From the 1974 Carnation Revolution, the 1966 unveiling of the Tagus bridge through to the Bosnian wars, all are captivatingly covered.

A Gestetner duplicator is on view, with the legend that it was one of the symbols of press freedom. 

Also shown is a vinyl record player and an array of TV cameras. A poster illustrates the 1960 American Presidential candidates, Kennedy and Nixon; the first television election.

The Portuguese Air Force has always been a relatively small organisation, and is currently facing some serious financial challenges.  Thus it is heartening to visit such an immaculate collection that celebrates the nation’s aviation heritage.

Located at Air Base #1 at Sintra , some 30 minutes from downtown Lisbon, the museum is a bit off the beaten track but well worth the effort.  Free parking, €3.00 entry for an adult (plus concessions) makes it fantastic value.  Guided visits are available on request, and audio guides can be provided.

The majority of the collection is held within two main hangars, one holding a large number of iconic types that have been central to Portugal’s military and civil aviation history.  A second, slightly smaller hangar, is actually formed from three historic buildings dating back to the 1920s and focuses on light aviation, foreign military campaigns and advanced jet training and VIP aircraft.

The aircraft are immaculately presented and while many carry typical examples of weapons, larger transport are displayed with doors or hatches open to enable the visitor to see inside.  The hangar walls are covered in interpretation boards, though only in Portuguese, although some of the aircraft interpretation boards have English translation.

There is a cafe (though closed, perhaps they don’t get enough visitors in December), and a small shop.

If you harbour an interest in aviation, this is a must.  Great for kids too.  Most definitely recommended!

reviews/1/text: Great surfing, good restaurants and nice small bar next to beach. There is a sea water pool available too and a cliff top walk to the next beach with interesting flora and dinarsor footprints.  Umbrella available too.
reviews/2/text: This is a great beach for enjoying nature. We stayed close by and visited the beach every day during our stay. The strong point of this beach are the views and enjoying walking alongside the waterline. Just observing the sea is fantastic here. If you like to swim head over to the pool at the hotel and for eating there are several good options.
reviews/3/text:
It's a great place with a long sandy beach , beautiful landscape and clean water. 
Free parking and shower all along the beach. 
There are some restaurants as well.
We had a good time when the tide was low ,however, be careful when the tide is high : rough waves 
Drive carefully: some parts of the road outside Colares are very narrow!
reviews/4/text: We went to a restaurant there for lunch and whjile at it we took a very nice a long walk on the beach. It was November, so no change of swimming, and the specific day was really windy so there were huge waves but the beach is beautiful! Would like to come back during summer time.
reviews/5/text: We stopped briefly at the beach which on a sightseeing trip and were impressed by the wide expanse of clean sandy beach. Not overly busy on a warm but blustery Monday.
reviews/6/text: We stopped here for a drink and enjoyed the views and the ocean. A popular spot for swimming and surfing
reviews/7/text: A beach for everybody. Lots of hard sand for beach games. Big waves for surfing. A very sandy beach. Lots of restaurants along the road which runs parallel to the beach. Several coffee spots along the promenade. At one end of the beach there is a huge sea water swimming pool which belongs to a hotel but it is open, for a fee, for others to use. There are indeed steps up to the cliff top at the opposite end of the beach to the swimming pool. However, these are closed due to a construction problem with the steps. There is another way up to the main road and thus onwards to the coastal path which is by the small roundabout just by the end of the road along the beach. At the opposite end of the beach above the swimming pool there is an easy path to the next beach.
reviews/8/text:
Personally I really like this beach although I acknowledge it has some not so good points. 

I like the cliffs, the waves and the sunset. You can go up the stairs in the cliffs and see the dinossaur footstep. From up there you can walk all the way to Cabo da Roca. You also can walk in the other direction to Praia das Maçãs, Azenhas, Magoito, Samarra, all the way to Ericeira.

You also have an amazing swimming pool with 100 meters, perfect to swim.

Good beach to learn to surf and bodyboard. But better for low tide, especially for beginners. Lots of schools to choose.

Lots of good restaurants, Bar do Fundo, Angra, Galé, right on top of the beach. 

The not so good points is the weather is quite unstable. You can get really foggy and cold days in the summer. The sea is cold, rough and strong but a lot of fun. With low tide is better.
reviews/8/title: Great beach, big waves, big cliffs, great restaurants, great sunshine
reviews/9/text: A nice drive west from Sintra and the signs lead you to Praia Grande.  A huge flat sandy beach with large rocks at the southern end.  Breathtaking!  Nice restaurants across the road with awesome sardines!
reviews/10/text: A humungus Beach with plenty of space.  Lovely sand for the kids. Surf schools and professionals in the water.  Good brakes but do check out the forecast if you are a beginner, it might be  some currents around.

reviews/12/text: The beach is good. The waves are rough. Good for surfing and sunbathing  or just to relax in the evenings.

reviews/16/text: Nice beach but very exposed. Go  for the sunbathing but could be anywhere, enjoyed an afternoon here but had seen it all

reviews/1/text:
We accidentally found this on the way to the Castle of the Moors, and the signs indicated that this was a way to get there, so we hiked it. It was a rainy day and we had our hiking boots on and so we were good to go. There were few others doing so, but it was a very lovely challenge with rewards along the way. Vila Sassetti and its fountain are very pretty, but the waterfalls and the journey itself are the real stars. 

The few other tourists along the way all encouraged each other as we went, and it was really a solid hike. On this particular day there was low cloud cover, rain, fog, and we hiked through some mud. This day was, for me, the best day of the trip. I want to return to do this on a cool and sunny day!
reviews/1/title: If you like to hike...take this way to get to the Castle of the Moors
reviews/2/text: The walk down after the Moorish Castle was wonderful. Steep steps in parts of the beginning that could be tough for many walkers but the views up to the castle and the rock climbing cliffs were super. About halfway down you turn into the old Moorish walkway through the gardens around the Vila and it’s beautiful and easy walking. For the more adventurous overall- takes about 45 minutes and descends 1500 meters.
reviews/2/title: Great walk down from Moorish Castle
reviews/3/text: This is a challenging but rewarding hike that can be done between the Pena Palace and the town of Sintra, with the Vila Sassetti giving its name to the trail. I suggest going DOWN instead of up the trail, like the majority of people did, because it is quite steep with uneven steps of various construction. The scenery includes views of the the various castles--Moorish, Queens--and rocks to climb. Going down took about 45 minutes, and that included stopping to let people pass as well as admire the vistas.
reviews/3/title: Walk to it DOWN from Pena

reviews/4/title: Nice place on a great walk
reviews/5/text: It's a bit of a hike to Villa Sassetti, which one can continue up to the castle.The gardens are impressive and really peaceful.
reviews/5/title: A Free Space in Sintra for a beautiful hike
reviews/6/text: Actually discovered it on our way down a trail from Pena. Views and garden area became a pleasant surprise. The footpath itself is rather steep, so if you plan to explore the Pena Palace or Moorish Castle it may be better to take a more sloping path up and then come down the route via vila Sassetti.
reviews/6/title: Nice surprise on the way down from Pena
reviews/7/text: We found this gem as we were hiking down the trail from Pena into Sintra central.  This is quite a nice little Villa and would be a great place to have a wedding. Be sure to look for the tile work on the building and all of the plants and flowers that are in bloom.
reviews/8/text: We refused to pay the tut-tut, so we started walking up the hill to the palace.  We walked by it, and it is really pretty.  The walk was strenuous but manageable.  But you are rewarded with a nice work-out and beautiful view going up the mountain.  I was glad I did it.
reviews/9/text: Vila Sassetti is an old villa style house once the home of wealthy folk. It is being restored but is not yet open to the public. The relatively small grounds however are open and are well kept and interesting with many plants, trees and a small pond. The Vila is halfway along the hiking trail between the old town and the Moorish Castle and is a good point to catch your breath and admire the scenery. I believe there is a small café and some toilets nearby also.
reviews/9/title: Interesting stop on the hiking trail.
reviews/10/text: This is a great way to either go up or down the mountain to visit the castle or Pena Palace. It's an easy trail that takes more or less an hour and a half each way, if you're stopping to take lots of pictures as you should. It's a trail locals like to do also, as from kids we get used to go to the castle through these trails. Enjoy!
reviews/11/text: We did not enter the Vila, but it is on the way up/down the hiking path to/from the Castle of the Moors and Pena Palace.  It has a beautiful garden area that you walk through on the way to the hiking trails.  Vila Sassetti has a uniquely beautiful style, and worth a stop.  The grounds are a great resting point on the journey to/from the higher palaces.
reviews/12/text: We didn't visit the villa itself, but took the footpath that goes through the grounds up to the Pena Palace and loved every step! The footpath is incredibly well designed to get you up the hillside without too much effort and the grounds and landscaping are so beautiful that you're distracted from the climb and reach the top before you know it (less than an hour from the main part of town)! The path was very well marked and easy to follow, and has restrooms and a snack bar along the way! Definitely a wonderful way to avoid the insane car traffic and reach the palace (or Moorish Castle) in a much happier state of mind!
reviews/13/text:
As I wrote in my review of the Pena palace, we chose to come back to Sintra by walking down the "pedastrian Route" which starts not far from the palace, and goes down, via Vila Sassetti into Sintra.
In one of the pictures I attach to the Pena palace review (I can't seem to find a way to attach photos here... will look for it thereafter) , I have showed a scan of the map for the start of this walk (The pedestrian Route - you can get a map of it too), with explanation what we did and what one should do... The whole walking path is nice, going through the woods, and then through the colorful and waterful gardens of the Vila - very nice and worth a visit; It took us a little over an hour; it has a few steps / stairs along the route, but still in my mind it is an easy walk (we went down... not up)
reviews/13/title: On the way down from Pena palace - a nice walk ~1+ hour; easy
reviews/14/text: The palace is not open yet, but you can take a stroll in the garden for free. There's a small brook that runs through the garden and a serpentine pathway to the top. This is a real gem for budget travelers as there's no entrance fee.
reviews/14/title: Nice garden route that leads to a trail to a view point, the Pena Palace and Moorish castle
reviews/15/text: We started at Pena Castle, walked to the Castle of the Moors and as recommended by our guest house, took the Villa Sassetti Pedestrian Footpath down to Sintra. Not realizing that Villa Sassetti was a place, we were pleasantly surprised to happen upon a clean WC on the trail which it turns out was on the edge of the Villa Sassetti grounds. While hiking boots aren't needed, I do not recommend walking down the trail in sandals.
reviews/15/title: beautiful grounds and gardens at the end of the Villa Sassetti Pedestrian Footpath
reviews/16/text:

The main attraction are the fabulous gardens and walking tracks that lead from the tone of Sintra all the way up to the castle.
The tracks are fully restored and easy to follow with plenty of signage. No tourist crowds here going up and down.

reviews/16/title: Fantastic walk up the mountain to the castle
reviews/17/text:

If you take the hiking trail between the castle and/or Park of Pena down to the the city centre, you'll pass Vila Sassetti. The garden grounds here are very well manicured and the villa is a delightful property to look over from the outside.
