reviews/1/text:
Obviously the star attraction here is the palace itself but the gardens are also very beautiful. I’d recommend doing battle with the crowds and seeing the palace first, then unwind by meandering through these extensive and relatively peaceful gardens.
The Vale dos Lagos (Valley of the Lakes) is a particularly pretty part which starts just below the palace and runs gently downhill towards the lower exit gates.  The lakes are a series of small man-made ponds, rather than great lakes but as you stroll beside them, you’ll see fish, snowy white geese, a lush entanglement of greenery, ferns and mossy walls and grottoes. An unexpected delight towards the end is a number of charming duck-houses. Sitting in the middle of the lake, they look like small castles, complete with turrets. Clearly someone had a taste for the whimsical. 
If you are exiting the park at this point, you are right beside a bus-stop and across the road are the trail heads for the Sasetti and the Santa Maria hiking trails.
reviews/1/title: Romantic Garden Walk through Valley of the Lakes
reviews/2/text:
In the rush to see the major landmarks of Sintra, it's easy to 'do' the Palace of Pena, hot-foot it across to the Moorish Castle and then onto the next stop on your itinerary. If you do, you'll be missing one of the highlights of the Sintra Hills.

The Parque de Pena and the Vale dos Lagos within it have a fairytale-like quality, with its towering trees, dainty bridges, chain of lakes and mini waterfalls, lush green ferns, tiny chapel, moss-covered benches and other man-made structures being slowly consumed by the undergrowth. And despite the crazy number of people at the palace, the size of the park and its labyrinthine paths make it easy to lose yourself in this beautiful setting. We wandered around for an hour and didn't see a soul for 20 minutes of that time. Bliss.

reviews/0/text:
Visits to Sintra from Lisbon start and finish at the rail station which is located along Ave. Dr. Miguel Bombarda, a 10-15 minutes walk east of historic centre and busy sightseeing area. The station was built 1887 and has a simple but attractive exterior along with a small interior with walls lined with azulejos tiled artworks. 

You can purchase tickets at the self-service machine within the station, at the ticket booth when open as well as a self-service machine at the end of the two platforms where there is also an station entrance. 

If connecting to/from Lisbon airport, you can use rail service between Oriente and Sintra Stations. Service is fairly regular and takes around 1 hour. Otherwise, if you are travelling from within Lisbon, you are more likely to use service to/from Rossio Station which takes around 40 minutes. 

There are several tourist buses which start just outside the rail station taking passengers to various palaces and gardens located dotting the hillsides above the Historic Centre of Sintra. You can also find taxi and uber drivers with ease as well. There are several casual espresso bars and eateries on the street just outside the rail station if you need to wait a few minutes for our outbound train back to Lisbon.

It couldn't be easier to get the train from Lisbon for a day trip. It was simple and cheap and the train station is only a 10 min walk from the town. My best tip is to save Sintra for a day when you can make an early start and then head to the Pena Palace first. 
TIPS:
* We caught the train from Rossio Station, using a rechargeable Via Viagem card (€4.50 return). It’s a 40 min trip from Lisbon.
* Trains are frequent and run every 10 min in peak times (20 or 30 min at other times)
* We arrived at Sintra Station around 10am which was later than we’d intended. In hindsight, arriving an hour earlier would have made a big difference.  
* The station is small and therefore is easy to find your way around.
* As you exit the station, head to your right to go straight to the 434 Scotturb buses which do a constant loop from the station to Pena Palace and the Castle (€3.90 & €6.90 for hop on/off). 
* Importantly, your Via Viagem card won’t work on the Sintra buses. 
* From the station, tuk tuks or ubers are another option to get to the palace and castle and there are hiking trails too (very steep). 
* The town centre is only a 10 min walk from the train station. If going here first, then head away from the buses and head downhill until you get to the palace-like Town Hall. Turn left here and follow the Volta do Duche road into town which is a very easy pleasant walk.

Looking more like a small palace than a town hall, this is the first sight you come to if you are walking from the train station into the old town. 
As far as town halls go, this is an extravagant one. Built in 1909, its fanciful architecture features towers, faux battlements, green, white and gold glazed spires and stylised arched windows. The fairy-tale appearance seems at odds with the ordinary, mundane matters of local transport, housing, sanitation and land use that goes on inside and because it is a working building, it’s not open to the public. 
The tall coloumn out the front is a pelourinho or pillory. Back in the day, law-breakers were punished by being tied to the base of these columns and publicly humiliated – an old school version of naming and shaming. 
If you continue the walk into Sintra’s historic centre, you will also pass a series of sculptures and artworks along the roadside and an enormous Moorish fountain.

reviews/0/text:
The star attraction at Sintra is the colourful Pena Palace but Sintra is also surrounded by beautiful mountains and extensive forests. The Serra de Sintra mountains start in the centre of the old town and extend to the ocean at Cabo da Roca, the western-most point of mainland Europe. 
Even if, like us, you only have a day-trip to Sintra, there are still hiking trails between the palaces and castle that allow you to see something of the mountains. 
After visiting Pena Palace, we followed the bushland trail to the Moors Castle and then continued the mountain trail around the outer castle walls, following the path right down through the forest to the old town centre. It was almost entirely downhill so was very easy.
We joined the track from the carpark opposite the lower Pena Park gate (the Lakes entrance). 
The path here was just a simple bushland track and there was a little bit of scrambling involved. We weren’t always 100% certain that we were still on the right path but we followed the general direction of the castle and emerged at the right spot (the outer walls of the castle beside the road, a kiosk and a toilet block). From here the route became much clearer, there were occasional signs and the path was mostly paved or cobbled. There are some great panoramic views as you descend and you will also pass the 12th century Gothic church of Santa Maria. 
The walk took us under an hour but we walked at a leisurely pace, stopping to look at the views.
TIPS
 * The Tourist Information Centre map was somewhat helpful as a general guide. If you don't already have a better map, then I’d recommend picking this up before you go because neither the Palace Gift shop nor the ticket office had any maps.
* Look out for wooden signs and trail markers that are red and yellow lines painted on a walls, rocks or tree. 
* there was plenty of shade and you didn't need special hiking shoes, just comfortable walking shoes or trainers but do take a bottle of water with you.

The Moorish Fountain (Fonte Mourisca) is located along Volta do Duche. This is delightful public fountain designed by José da Fonseca (1922) and embraces Moorish features and design including a jagged arched entrance, outer horseshoe as well as symmetric teal tiled facade. You can walk into the half-moon shaped interior where you find seats, relief from the sun or rain as well as spout pouring spring water into a basin below.  

Overall, the Moorish Fountain might be the pretties of the handful of decorative street fountains around Sintra. It is picturesque and  a neat place to find (and to stop for water bottle refills) while exploring the city.

reviews/3/text:
This large public water fountain is one of the sights that you pass if you are walking from the train station into the old town along the Volta do Duche. It looks centuries old but surprisingly it’s nowhere near as as old as it looks and was only built in 1922. However the revivalist design harks back to 13th/14th century Moorish architecture with an exaggerated arabesque style. The entrance is formed by three large horse-shoe arches and it’s covered in the highly decorative and traditional azulejos tiles. 
It’s not a must-see on its own but you can fill your water bottle here and the Volta do Duche walk has several other interesting sights, including the whimsical Town Hall and pillory and a series of large sculptures and artworks.

This property located near the Lourel, Sintra, is made up of the Manor of Ribafria, gardens and green spaces.
The Manor was built in 1541 by Gaspar Gonçalves, during the reign of King Manuel I, who conferred on him the title of the landlord of Ribafria.
The Manor, Manueline architecture, is one of the most beautiful examples of Portuguese civil architecture, with a tower of about 30 m high. All property needs renovation works.

reviews/7/text:
If you like to find places that only a few ever heard of, this is the place (or should i say Palace...) to go!

Solar de Ribafria ordered the construction in 1541, in the reign of D. Manuel I.

It's name, Ribafria is due to Lordship of Ribafria, who was allowed to gave his nickname to the property.

The Palace was designed with straith and sober lines and it's consider a fine example of portuguese "Manuelino" architecture style.
From the Palace structure, a 30 metter (100 ft) quadrangular tower stands out from the building. It's said that it was meant to watch the sea and all the surroundings that belonged to the same Ribafria Lordship.
Facing the Palace it's possible to see, in the right upper side, the coat of arms (in stone). It's shape is peculiar because it looks like it's gonna fall from the corner...

The Palace have, in front of it, a great water mirror that "builts" a reflection of its magnificent frontage.

Convolving this scenery, luxuriants tall trees provide the shadow for a perfect walk (romantic, family and even with a adventure felling).

Another curiosity it's the XVI century "swimming pool". It's a must!!

And, of course, the small chappel.

I hope all this tips will make you visit this Palace that is suffering a structural renovation that will allow it to be an hotel in the near future.

Came and see while its raw and pure...

reviews/4/text: Great place to walk around what ever the weather although a fine day did add to the beautiful scenery. Nice displays but a lot of steps and some of the walk ways narow and with more than a 100 ft drop on the other side of the wall it can be a bit exilerating.
reviews/5/text: If you are already in the Cabo de Roca area, this is worth the short detour.  While it's a short distance, it won't be a quick drive, as the roads up to the parking lot are narrow (but well-paved, and safe).  On a clear day, though, it's worth it, as the views are stunning, and even in peak season this place had only a few visitors.
reviews/6/text:
The Peninha convent is a beautiful structure that is almost in ruins, but is has some of the best views you can have around Lisbon. You should go by car, as no public transport will get you even close to this place. By car, it is a 20 minute drive from Sintra and an hour drive from Lisbon. You can park there, there is a lot of space, and then you have to walk in a steep road for maybe 5-7 minutes until the top, where you can reach this stunning place. From the top you can see all the coastline until the Espichel cape, and also you have a beautiful forest scenery to the other side of this convent. A lot of stairs in the convent as well, it is closed, but the views from the outside are gorgeous. It is always a bit windy up there, so if you have kids better to cover them in scarfs and winter caps, otherwise they will get very cold. Usually the weather is very uncertain over there, sunny for 10 minutes, and windy and cloudy for half an hour. When it is very cloudy, you cannot enjoy the views completely, but you can always see something, and this something is already magnificent. 
Comfy shoes are a must! :) and then, you can take a look around the trails as well. It is a very romantic spot, and it is never crowded :) so you can really enjoy the views!
reviews/7/text: Now that I know about this place, I will bring friends and family who visit here instead of braving the hordes at Pena Palace. For far less stress (and crowds) you can take in the unique ruins and their beautiful colors, enjoy climbing around on your own, and take in a panoramic view from Ericeira to the north to Setúbal and Lisbon to the south. You can also use this as a picnic spot, or a jumping off point for a hike on the yellow/red coastal trail. The forests surrounding the convent are magical. Bring the pups as well! For the most spectacular colors, go right before sunset. Plus...it's free!
reviews/7/title: Cool Ruins, Amazing View, Good Hikes

reviews/10/text: We were driving toward Cascais, and considering the beautiful clear weather our guide recommended to make a short detour to this place.  We did not visit the tiny convent (not clear if possible, but not the purpose of our visit), but the view was astounding, over 180 degrees over the coast. With the right weather conditions, I certainly recommend including this quick stop in a driving tour of the area.
reviews/11/text: It was raining so maybe that was why it was uninspiring. But we walked around a bit and got drenched.
reviews/11/title: Not much going on, but nice location.
reviews/12/text: Absolutely well worth a visit. Certainly out of the way but incredible. The views are amazing. This is not a tourist spot. It's defintely a place full of beauty and nature.
reviews/13/text: You park in a small car park below the Convent and walk up a steep stony path, as you turn the corner you start to see the view.......... only one word 'WOW'
reviews/14/text:
Capela da Peninha (or Capela de Nossa Senhora da Pena), a church from the XVII-XVIII centuries with an interesting baroque style interior. It was closed when I visited it.
Facing the ocean you can see at your right Cabo da Roca, the most occidental point in continental Europe,  and the light house, for the left the extensive coastal line until Cascais. A beautiful view to the ocean or to Sintra Woods, depending to where you look. 
The convent was closed so you just can walk around. A little bit windy. Some meters west you can find the Ermida de S. Saturnino (St. Saturnino Hermitage), in disrepair unfortunately.  A building from XVI and XVII centuries, but a more ancient worship place (a previous building was demolished to give place to the actual chapel; the place was, supposedly, founded by a companion of Portugal's first king). During a part of XX century was used as a house or barn.
Archaeological excavations also found a necropolis from  XII-XV centuries and the remains of other buildings, like a cistern.
The wood surrounding is really pleasant and some hike trails are signed.
You can walk from Sintra; It took me around 3-4 hours walking. From here you can go down to Cabo da Roca walking through the paths on the forest (not signed, which can be tricky).   

You can find some information about the sanctuary when you approach the place (at least in portuguese).
reviews/15/text: From here you can best see Cascais from top to the south. To the west you can see Cabo de Roca, the westernmost point in continental Europe. The small church was closed and there is not too much to do except enjoying the view. There is no fee to access the place. The woods are quite nice, humid and special, with their own microclimate. You can expect to be a little windy. You can trail a little around, but get a GPS so you wont get lost, the forest can be tricky and the paths are not well marked. The parking is limited so you may have to park in the woods and the access road is thin so drive slow.
reviews/15/title: One of the best panoramas in Sintra and Lisbon region.
reviews/16/text:
Après avoir parcouru 3/4 kms en voiture vous bifurquez sur la droite dans un petit chemin de terre (carrossable c'est à noter) et un parking (non surveillé) permet de se garer facilement. 

Un petite montée à pied vous amènera sur un premier point de vue. 

Dans un second temps n'hésitez pas à vous rapprocher du bâtiment abandonné qui surplombe le sommet. Prenez les quelques escaliers qui vous amèneront devant une magnifique porte et une petite terrasse où vous pourrez faire de superbes photos. 

Coin pour les amoureux, très calme (à voir en saison). 

Un lieu (avec la pointe du phare plus bas) où le coucher de soleil est magnifique !!
reviews/17/text:
O Santuário da Peninha é misto de Santuário com estação militar/metereologica que aparenta estar ao abandono. Quando lá fui estava uma ventania que não se podia. Vê-se o Santuário do Cabo da Roca e vice-versa ora pois.
Se a vossa Maria gosta de fotos assim mais artsy farsty para o Instagram, então ela vai adorar o Santuário da Peninha, caso contrário em meia hora dá para ver tudo, sacar umas chapas e continuar caminho.

reviews/18/text:
Per capire la geografia di un posto puoi usare la tecnica classica: stendere una carta, orientarla con la bussola, trovare i riferimenti reali e leggerla. Puoi anche usare una di quelle app di mappe che si autoorientano col GPS (mangiando la batteria a morsi...).
Oppure - come hanno sempre fatto i nostri vecchi - sali in alto quanto basta per vedere. Una bella salita dal parcheggio (forse da fare prima di merenda e non dopo...) e arrivi in un posto splendido, dove la forza del vento ti fa capire che sei abbastanza in alto. E li non occorre cartina: hai tutto sotto gli occhi... Un buon binocolo o un semplice monocolo ti regalerà vedute splendide. E se hai l'avvertenza di fare foto con una buona ottica, questo è il posto...

reviews/1/text:
This large public park, created in 1936, is one of the sights that you pass if you are walking from the train station into the old town along the Volta do Duche. It’s not a must-see but if you want to avoid walking along the road, then you can cut down through the park. Entry is free. Look out for a staircase on your right just after the Town Hall which will take you down into the park . 
Although we only used it as a shortcut, the park is quite large and has clear paths through lush growth, a pond and fountain, a duck-house and a playground.

reviews/2/text: Rather than take a bus etc. or walk up the road to the Moorish Castle from the station with the crowds, we decided to wander through this pleasant park and other paths. It made the climb on a hot day a lot more pleasant than otherwise would have been the case.

reviews/2/text:
We stopped off here on our trip up to see the moorish castle. Entry cost €1 each, and we were greeted by a lady who spoke Portuguese and French. She explained the history of the museum, layout and exhibitions to us in French (I did French for 4 years at school so managed to catch about 50% of what she was saying). 
The first floor had a film and some beautiful pictures of space. Unfortunately we were hurried downstairs by one of the guides, even though we hadn't finished looking around. He only spoke Portuguese so I don't know why we were made to leave. 
The second floor was split into different areas which coincided with what time period the fossils were from. It was hard to distinguish which fossils were what as the numbered explanations did not match up and were often in the wrong place. We were also under the impression that some of the fossils were actually replicas, but this was hard to tell as most of the explanations were in Portuguese. 
Overall, we spent about 30 minutes here. I think it is worth coming here if you have small children, but don't expect anything ground breaking.
reviews/3/text: We enjoyed an hour in hereand found it quite interesting. It i basically the collection/work of one man.

I really enjoyed this museum but had 2 complaints.A majority of the 
exhibits had only Portuguese so I lost some of the display information and secondly, I felt as though there wasn't a good flow from one room to another. reviews/5/text:
This was the private collection of Miguel Barbosa before being donated to the public.  As such, it doesn't have the huge range and variety of a major museum, but it has enough!

The entry level has a Triceratops skull near the door, and a reconstruction of a flying reptile skeleton suspended from the ceiling.  The basement level has loads of specimens - trilobites, bivalves, meteorite fragments, several large dinosaur skulls, lifesize models of both Deinonychus and Velociraptor, and more.

Entry fee was one Euro per person (over 12).
reviews/6/text: I had read that the museum was free, the staff were uninterested when we arrived until we walked through to the main room at which point we were rudely addressed. The rest of the exhibits were uninspired and the interactive screens refused to work for me. If it's raining then it's a cheap place to shelter from the rain but that's about all that is going for it.

reviews/0/text: If you like history this is a fascinating place to visit... the people in the museum will explain everything beautifully about history of the place..very nice
reviews/1/text: We came across this little museum by chance. We staying in Sintra and had walked to Quinta da Regaleira. On the way back we saw this museum. We had never heard of Ferreira De Castro. We went in and were cheerfully greeted at the reception. They asked if we were English and they gave us a typed booklet explaining every exhibit in the museum. It was fascinating. It turned out that he went to Brazil when he was twelve and worked on a rubber plantation, he went on to become a journalst and novelist who founded newpapers in Brazil and then Portugal when he returned. He wanted to be buried in Sintra and in the museum there is an unopened box of love letters that he asked to be kept closed until 2050. As we were leaving we were told we could keep the guide, which made fascinating reading. If you like books or history this is a fascinating plae to visit (and it's free, very unusual in Sintra!)

It is located right in the city center. It dates to the 12th & 13th centuries.
This parish church was destroyed by the 1755 earthquake and rebuilt out of character at the end of the 18th Century. Of the original structure there remain only the Gothic chancel, visible from outside, and three Portuguese paintings on wood from the middle of the 16th Century - "Saint Martin and the Beggar", "Saint Peter" and "Saint Anthony", attributable to the artist known as the Master of São Quintino.

There is a museum of sacred art and not inside it. But we didn't visit.
The visit will not take more than 15 minutes to discover and enjoy with no regrets.

reviews/0/text:
There are a handful of decorative fountains that you will see along various streets while exploring the Historic Centre of Sintra. One such fountain is called Fonte dos Piscoes (1931). It is located along Ave. Almeida Garret just a few minutes walk from the Quinta de Regaleira. 

Fonte dos Piscoes has a mostly light yellow colour with several sets of tiles including the centre pattern with blue and orange tiles along with a bas-reliefs of playful cherubs just above a single spout which spills water into a small basin just below and a larger on at ground level. 

During our recent visit water was pouring from the spout and spilling into a basin below, many visitors were topping up their water bottles, as did we. The fresh water tasted delicious.

reviews/0/text: This small museum is one of the sights you will pass when walking along the Volta do Duche, between the train station and the town centre. Entry is only €1 but for most people, limited time is the main problem. Fortunately, you can see some sculptures without going out of your way because they have placed several alongside the road for public viewing. Other art installations and modern sculptures by local artists have been added and it certainly makes the 10 min walk into town very pleasant.
reviews/1/text:
The national palaces and the moorish castle tend to dominate when it comes to planning a visit but there are several very fine little musuems to consider and which makes it highly desirable to spend at least one night, if not two, in Sintra. 
The Museu Anjos Teixeira falls into the small but very good category.  Even then, you should allow at least an hour to admire sculptures and drawings by both father Artur and son Pedro.
The collection is housed in Pedro's home, surprisingly secluded in a spot between the train station area and the Palacio Nacional.  A lovely walk to get there.

Museu Anjos Teixeira (Museum of Anjos Teixera) is an attraction in Sintra where you can see contemporary works of Portuguese sculptures, Arthur and Pedro Anjos Teixeira. 

The museum is located downhill from the curved street, Vulcha Dulche which links the area of Sintra around the rail station to the historic city centre area. 

In addition to the actual museum there are quite a few sculptures that have been placed along the Vulcha Dulche sidewalk as well. Like the Teixieira sculptures, these focus on contemporary human and animal representations, some of which are quite interesting to view if you are a fan of sculptures.

The former Sintra Museum of Modern Art, which held the Berardo collection (now at CCB, Centro Cultural de Belém, Lisbon) has indeed chenged its name to MU.SA - Museu das Artes de Sintra.

reviews/0/text:
Pillories like this were once an essential part of law and order in a Portugese town. They were always in a central place like in the main plaza or outside the town hall just like this one. Nowadays it looks like a decorative monument of some sort but back in the day, they had a very practical purpose. Criminals and other offenders were tied or chained to the base of the column and were often whipped. Some pillories still have the metal rings for tying prisoners up. The public location ensured maximum humiliation for the offender because there was no hiding. This was a medieval version of naming and shaming. 
This pillory has the typical feature of a highly decorative column. This one is entwined with rope-like sculptured patterning. At the top is an armillary sphere, with coats of arms and at the very pinnacle, a large cross of the Knights Templar.
This is the first sight you come to if you are walking from the train station into the old town. Continuing the walk into the historic centre, you will also pass a series of sculptures and artworks along the roadside and an enormous Moorish fountain.

reviews/0/text:
This 19th century fountain pavilion is one of the sights inside the gardens of the Pena Palace. The entire gardens are a wonderful indulgence of lush plantings, secret grottoes and a labyrinth of paths. The fountain is tucked away in a shady, secluded spot and has the pleasingly romantic name of Fountain of Small Birds. There’s a bench seat nearby which was a very pleasant and quiet spot to sit for a while. Surprisingly, after the madness of the palace crowds, this part of the garden felt like our own private space. No-one else came near it.
The Islamic styled fountain has decoratively tiled walls and is topped with a golden dome that has Arabic inscriptions running around it. I couldn't see any information about the inscription but I later found out that it says “The Sultan D. Manuel built this chapel in the name of Our Lady Mary of Pena, in the year 1503, in celebration of the safe return of Dom Vasco da Gama’s discovery of the lands and countries which he found, the Cape of Good Hope and India. For His Highness the Sultan Ferdinand II, husband of Her Majesty Queen Maria II, built it with royal magnificence in the year 1840”.
Strangely the inscription refers to the King Ferdinand refers to himself as a Sultan. Im not sure why but Ferdinand clearly had a taste for whimsy and this was perhaps just another of his fanciful ideas.
From here, we walked past the Garden of Camellias and the most stunning magnolia trees, down through the Valley of the Lakes and finally to the lower exit.

reviews/7/text: para quem percorre as ruas de sintra pode encontrar qualquer coisa. esta fica num local que é fácil de encontrar. tem valor histórico, naturalmente mas hoje em dia ficou só uma ideia do passado. há um bar com o mesmo nome que fica perto.
reviews/8/text: Em um cantinho nessa cidade cheia de tesouros escondidos, encontro mais um em um de suas ladeiras. A Fonte da Pipa e encantadora, com um belo painel de azulejos. Só precisa de um pouco mais de cuidado, pois o local parece estar abandonado.
reviews/9/text: Encore une jolie fontaine dans le centre de Sintra, il y en a plusieurs et on passe souvent devant par hasard. Mais celle-ci est un peu dans les hauteurs, on l'aperçoit du bas de la rue. C'est comme cela que nous nous y sommes rendus. Il y a de beaux azulejos sur les côté.
reviews/10/text: המזרקה משכה את תשומת ליבנו. בסצינות האזוז'לוש שעליה,בחלקם חסרים אריחים.היתה מקור מים לתושבים,אך כיון אינה בשימוש.על האריחים חרוטה שנת 1787,אך איננו יודעים אם זו השנה שבה נבנתה.
reviews/11/text: Preciosa fuente, tan portuguesa, con sus azuleios azules, da para algunas fotos y selfies en el lugar.  Solo la encontrarán quienes se aventuren a recorrer las tortuosas callejuelas de la villa.  Ahora ya no brolla agua de ellas, pero aún así, son realmente bonitas.
reviews/12/text: É só uma fonte antiga, mas combina com o charme da cidade. Não é difícil de achar, é só caminhar um pouco pelo centro.
reviews/13/text: Fonte histórica da Vila de Sintra que tem uma pequena pipa onde saía a água... Agora já só é parte de museu pois não é utilizada para consumo de água.
reviews/14/text: こちら自体は、お水の源で古い時代からの施設です。私は、この周りの光景がとても気に入りました。小さな細い路地の角で見つけたのですが、時を感じるタイル貼りの装飾がとてもこの地にしっとりと似合っていまして、静かに時間が少し止まっていた気がします。飾ることのない素朴な唯一無二の光景でした。
reviews/15/text: Синтра - само очарование. Кроме основных достопримечательностей, в Синтре чудесная атмосфера самобытных улочек. Одна из таких улочек (Rua Fonte da Pipa) ведет к месту, которое раньше было питьевым источником городка.
reviews/16/text:
A fonte já abasteceu moradores da vila.Hoje já não jorra água em sua bica. 
       Parece ser muito antiga. Há uma data gravada - 1787 - mas esta não se refere a sua inauguração e sim a uma intervenção do reinado de D Maria I. Por algum tempo a água foi desviada para servir a uma propriedade particular e, por ordem real, a água foi restituída à população. O texto da inscrição está desgastado pelo tempo.
       Sua denominação decorre do formato de sua bica , o de uma pipa (barril).
       É ornamentada por painéis de azulejos.
reviews/17/text:
Tja, als je het historische verhaal er achter niet kent is het een tegelplateau met een fontein waar geen water uit komt....
Dus als je gaat kijken (wat bij een wandeling door Sintra heel goed te doen is), ga dan eerst lezen waar de fontein voor staat. 
Sintra zelf is als attractie vergelijkbaar met Cascais.

reviews/1/text: Originally built in Romano-Gothic style, the Church of St. Martin was damaged during the Great Earthquake. Although it stood at the base, but it was not safe to hold services and therefore it underwent reconstruction, which changed its appearance. The most notable is the red-and-gold baroque altar. Several paintings by local artists date back to the 16th century. Otherwise, everything is modest.
reviews/1/title: Old church rebuilt after Great Earthquake.
reviews/2/text: Just walking by and came upon this church worthy of mention.  I understand the original church in the 1100s  didn't survive the 1755 earthquake; nor did the priest celebrating mass at that moment.  We have seen the resurrected Jesus wearing purple just like this one elsewhere.
reviews/3/text: A nice church, with some lovely architecture, and a history, well worth a visit, if your in the area.
reviews/4/text:
Igreja de Sao Martinho is a deceptively large and beautiful church in SIntra. It doesn't look like much from the outside. A church since from the 13th century, the current incarnation only dates back to the 18th Century after it was destroyed by an earthquake. The interiors is very much Romanesque with it barrel vault and rounded arches, with beautiful, but not exceptional interiors.

Not a must see, but worth a quick look if you have time in Sintra. They do have a small museum which will give a lot more historical information about the church.
reviews/5/text: Don't miss this little church. We didn't expect to see a church that clearly shows it's Romanesque origins. It dates back to the 12th century, but has been modified (modernized i guess) over time and now also shows Gothic elements. The 1755 eat quake allowed for some further changes. Of interest are the 3 16th century paintings, painted on wood panels as well as some very old frescos on the walls and ceiling. The altar definitely feels old. The church is located in the heart of Old Sintra. Walk around the church and look for the best angle for a shot of the bell tower with the Moorish castle in the background.
reviews/6/text: Gegen eine kleine Spende, wird man auch durch die Räume der Kirche geführt, die sonst nicht zu besichtigen sind, mit den Schätzen der Kirche
reviews/7/text: La Iglesia de Sao Martinho quedo muy deteriorada en el terremoto del año 1.755 y tuvo que ser reconstruida según el estilo que tenía en el momento del accidente. Su interior es un remanso de paz con obras de arte en sus paredes.
reviews/7/title: BELLA IGLESIA EN EL CENTRO DE SINTRA
reviews/8/text: Una bella Chiesa cattolica vicina a palazzo National di origine romanica,fu danneggiata dal terremoto del 1755 e quindi ricostruita secondo gli usi del 700 e cosi' e' rimasta,piccola ma interessante.
reviews/9/text: Uma bela Igreja dedicada a São Martinho o famoso Santo que cortou a sua capa para dar a um mendigo no meio de uma tempestade. Ao fazer isso a tempestade parou e o Sol apareceu. A lenda data do ano de 337. Seu data é comemorada em 11 de novembro. Um ex-soldado Romano que se tornou Monge. A igreja é pequena, mas interessante.
reviews/10/text: 宮殿からほど遠くないところにありました。質素な教会です。でも、とてもきれいに整備されていました。教会の裏側からの景色は最高でした。
reviews/11/text: Igreja bonita de interesse histórico e de grande importância arquitectónica,com uns interiores bonitos,e com um exterior que nos oferece uma vista magnífica em todas as direcções de Sintra.

reviews/0/text:
On our 4th day of the tour, we were bused to the palace of Queluz. The palace’s architecture was inspired by the Versailles. The biggest difference is Queluz is not as opulent nor ornate. Much of the wall decoration and ceiling decoration were done with painting instead of actual wood carving or gold-plated paint. 
There are plenty of chandeliers through out the palace - worth spending time to enjoy the details of each of them. 
The grounds were manicured beautifully, patterned after French gardens. Not as big in size - still very enjoyable !! 
If you have time in Lisbon, do visit this palace !
